posts.caption:
Semi-retired to me is being able to work a less stressful job and less hours for less pay so I can spend more time with my family and more time creating personal finance and investing content.

What does your ideal “semi-retired” life look like?

Let me know in the comments.

Most people don’t realize that “semi-retired” is a thing. Usually you just work til you’re 65. And then you have a retirement party. And then you just completely stop working.

But truthfully, there are endless options to design a “semi-retirement” if you have the financial means.

Investing as much as you can as early as you can is the best way to give yourself the option to potentially “semi-retire” if that interests you.

Stroller is @zoestrollers  @zoebabygear

#financialindependence #investing #financialindependenceretireearly #zoefam #rollwithzoe

Investing is for losers. I spend every dollar I make. Because…

Because I invested so much in my 20s and I now have $450K invested at 33. This money is going to stay invested for 25 more years and I’ll have $3-$5 million when I’m in my late 50s.

Comment “PORTFOLIO” and I’ll send you a link to see my entire portfolio of exactly which index funds I invest in. 

As a result, I don’t need to invest any more money for retirement. So I can spend every dollar I make. And we can afford for my wife to be a stay at home Mom.

This is called Coast Financial Independence. Or Coast FI. And it’s great.

Save and invest as much as you can in your 20s so you can set your self up for a lifetime of financial freedom. 

#investing #financialfreedom #financialindependence #retirement #retirementplanning #coastfi #financialindependenceretireearly

Comment “PORTFOLIO” and I’ll DM you a link to see my entire investment portfolio and exactly which index funds I invest in.

Index funds and ETFs are the easiest way to start investing. And even after 10 years of investing and a $430K investment portfolio. I literally just continue to buy the same handful of index funds.

Let me know if you have any questions!

#personalfinance #indexfunds #investing #retirement #bogleheads

My favorite quote - “I want to be in uncomfortable situations because that’s when you learn and grow”.

That quote is related to personal growth, but it still applies to personal finance. A little bit.

When you’re not investing aggressively enough, you probably have too much money sitting in your bank account and you’re comfortable and you don’t need to question purchases.

But I want you to be a little bit uncomfortable. I want you to be investing so much of your money that you need to question whether you can afford that new pair of pants this month.

I want you to be investing so much that you can’t afford to order doordash and you force yourself to make a dinner out of random stuff in your pantry.

When you’re not investing enough and you’re too comfortable, you’re not going to challenge yourself on spending and you’re going to waste money.

I’m not telling you to cut out everything fun in your life. But if you’re a bit uncomfortable and you’ve already spent money on going out for your friends birthday, then maybe you’ll question your spending on some unnecessary expense instead of just buying it anyways. 

I know this sounds a little Dave Ramsey-ish and I know this isn’t for everyone. But this is what I did throughout a lot of my 20s and it worked well for me.

Remember to automate all of your investing.

And remember that you need to have an emergency fund and be saving for short term goals in a HYSA.

2024: The Year of Rice and Beans.

Not to save money, but to improve your health.

Rice and beans get a bad rap for being the ultimate cheap food.

But regardless of cost, beans are one of the healthiest foods in the world.

Doesn’t that sound good? One of the healthiest foods is also one of the cheapest foods. Just gotta season them right.

Cheers to 2024 and eating more beans! Not to save money, but to improve our health! The saving money part is just another side benefit.

READ BELOW FOR WHY I’M HAPPY I INVESTED IN MY 20s ⬇️ 😀

When I was 23, I didn’t know why I was investing so much money (it was a lot for me). I just knew it was the right thing to do because of the power of compounding.

10 years later and I’m so happy that I invested what I did. It’s given our family a ton of financial security and flexibility.

I was too busy partying at 23 to even know what my life would like 10 years into the future. But now at 33, I can look back and at least share my journey and lessons with you all.

If you know you want a family in the future, you might as well start thinking a little bit about your financial future now.

It doesn’t have to be anything crazy, but if you’re wasting $500/month on junk, think about how much financial security and freedom that can provide your future family if you invest that $500 every month and you do that for 10 years.

It’s sometimes hard to picture that or imagine that far into the future. That’s why I’m so transparent about my finances on social media. So you can see what’s possible if you save/invest like I did. Even if you did half of what I did, you would still have a lot of money.

I’m not telling you to skip that trip with your friends or to eat at home every meal…I just want you to truly think about how you’re spending every dollar and make sure it aligns with you values and your future aspirations. Especially if you want a family.

Also, this video is 7 months old lol. I just never posted it from my drafts. But it’s cool that my net worth has grown from $540K to $600K in that timeframe. The power of investing.

The question I get the most is, “I have x amount of money. What should I do with it?”

I always refer people to the 7 steps that I show in this video.

They are the fundamental building blocks of personal finance and how your dollars should be deployed for you.

They are taken directly from the @reddit personal finance subreddit flow chart and I would say they apply to 90% of people unless you’re trying to invest heavy into real estate or your own business or something similar.

But for most people working a w2 job, these steps are going to apply.

Learn these steps and understand them so you can apply them to your life.

I don’t think it’s any harder than something you would learn in middle school and it’s going to have a much bigger impact on your life than geometry.

One of the big steps is getting your 401K match. It’s like free money from your employer. Just make sure you understand the vesting terms. But a 401K match is the only time in your life where you will get a 100% or 50% return on your money. So it’s a very advantageous thing to do.

#401K #personalfinance

Everyone always wants travel and have experiences in their 20s while they’re young. And I wanted those too.

But a dollar invested in your 20s is worth SO much more than a dollar invested in your 30s or 40s (when investing for 30-40 years).

So how do you balance this?

Cut back on things that don’t matter to you (in my case, living with roommates, driving a used car, cooking at home, etc.).

So you can spend money on the things that DO matter to you (experiences, travel, socializing with friends)…AND still have money to invest for your future.

Unless you have an extremely high income, you’re not going to be able to have the nicest apt, a brand new car, doordash dinner and eat out lunch, the fanciest clothes, travel all the time, and still save for retirement.

You simply can’t have everything, unless you want to work until you’re 70 years old. That’s why you need to prioritize your spending and if experiences/travel are important to you, then prioritize them, but you’re probably going to have to give something else up.
Trust me, you will feel the compound growth whenever it starts to kick in. It is a great feeling.
